WHAT DID EARLY CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. L. Stratford
Address: Ridgedale, Sask.
Birthplace: Ontario, Canada

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in eastern Canada? 1918
Where did you set up housekeeping? 24 miles north of Star City
Where had you been living before that? Montana
For how many people did you prepare meals? 10 and varied at times
How far was it to your nearest store? 3/4 mile
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every 2 or 3 weeks or so
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, salt, Royal Yeast Cakes, evaporated fruit, soda, corn starch, corn meal, tea, baking powder, oatmeal, coffee, soda crackers, cocoa

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Radium
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 5¢
How much did you use graham flour? 10 lbs
Whole wheat flour? No
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? about 40¢
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes
Whole wheat? Yes
Farina? Yes
Other? Oatmeal
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 25 lb. bag.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.45.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? None.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb., 2 lb., 4 lb.

At what price? $1.00, $1.50, $2.00.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From cows.

Did you have cows? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? No.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork or bought.

How did you get fresh meat? Butchered and kept in summer.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? In brine or dry salt.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not until in the 1930s.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Some.

What kinds? Turkey, a little.

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? Didn't have any.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Cured.

Kinds? Herring mostly.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ...........................................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Later we dug deep wells but water was hard and unpleasant taste but lots of it.

Later years we had ice from river for drinking purposes. Lots of rainwater always.

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)

Was any filtering or other treatment necessary?

First start local housekeeping, either at sea where possible.

Later we dug deep wells but lots of it and unpleasant taste but lots of it.

Later we had ice from river and rainwater for drinking purposes. Lots of rainwater always.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

1910
**Breakfast:** Oatmeal, Porridge, eggs and toast, butter, fruit, potatoes when hired man.
**Dinner:** Meat & Potatoes, vegetable, pudding, Bread & Butter or Pie.
**Supper:** Meat or eggs and Potatoes, fruit, stewed Bread & Butter, cake or cookies sometimes soup instead of meat.

---

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?
   ...1910........... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

   We were only two weeks married, & alone.
   Roast chicken and dressing.
   Potatoes, gravy.
   Christmas pudding & sauce.

---

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.
   No, but we had neighbors who came from Chicago and after two or three years their money running out. Man, wife, 2 small children, she told me they only bought four things—flour, salt, soda and coffee. They raised Rabbits for meat, and Moose in winter. Had some hens and a cow, and a garden of course.

   This was homestead land being taken up from 1905 until 1912. The roads were very bad, impassable some places and still not good. Although the best of land;
Myself and husband
